Award.AwardTitle: Integrating developmental morphogenetic theory and dental biodistance practices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Differences in the size and shape of teeth are used in a variety of ways, from reconstructing evolutionary relationships between species to identifying individuals in modern forensics cases. As such, it is critical that we understand how tooth size and shape are inherited by studying the dentition in family trees.

The Albert Dahlberg collection of dental casts is one of the largest in the world and consists of 7500 dentitions representing 3000 individuals. Most individuals are situated in known family trees thus allowing the researchers to explore the genetics of how dental characteristics are passed between generations. Previous work on the collection has contributed to our understanding of dental genetics, development, and evolution; however, the full potential of this archive has never been realized. Recent advances in developmental biology, genetic statistical tools and software, and 3D scanning technology now permit an exploration of tooth genetics in ways not previously possible, while scanning will also preserve this fragile resource for use by future generations.

The project will record a comprehensive set of metric and nonmetric data from the collection. Using these data, project staff will generate heritability estimates for a large number of dental features using large sample sizes and complex statistical models. The project will also explore how dental features infer evolutionary relationships and how they identify closely related individuals based on their dental similarities. The dissemination of highly accurate digital models of the casts will provide researchers with the needed data to test a number of assumptions about how tooth size and shape are inherited and modified by evolutionary mechanisms.

The project will benefit anthropology, developmental biology, paleontology, clinical dentistry and forensic dentistry. The larger significance is making this collection widely available to remote researchers, who will be able to mine and analyze the data in currently unknown ways for generations to come.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many people don’t think about their teeth unless there is a problem. Yet teeth are one of the most useful and informative parts of the body. The outer enamel is the hardest substance in the human body and the dentition of an individual preserves important information about growth, the health of the individual, and what they ate. This is why archaeologists are so interested in the study of teeth from ancient societies – analyses of dentition provide unique windows into the lives of our ancestors, both relatively recent and ancient. Indeed, much of what we know about the deep past of life on this planet comes from teeth that have fossilized. Teeth are used to reconstruct evolutionary relationships between different species, to infer body size, and to reconstruct habitat and dietary focus. For humans, teeth are an important source of information on genealogical relationships, how cemeteries were organized, migration patterns, and patterns of relatedness between ancestor and descendant communities. The utility of teeth is more so evident in situations in which DNA does not preserve. But the relationship between tooth anatomy and genetics is poorly understood. This project’s ultimate goal is to improve our understanding of the relationships between genes and tooth appearance to better inform the analysis of evolutionary relationships in the past using the human skeleton as a proxy.

To accomplish this, we proposed a scope of work that focused on collections of human dental casts (Figure 1) that were accompanied by genealogical information detailing how the individuals were related to each other (Figure 2). We collected data on tooth size, approximately three dozen standard observations on tooth anatomy (such as the number of cusps on a molar), scaled two dimensional images of the premolars and molars (to allow assessment of the arrangement of features on the chewing surface of the tooth– Figure 3), and three dimensional scans of complete dental casts (Figure 4).  These data were recorded from dental casts for two different populations: 1) approximately 450 individuals from the Solomon Islands collected during the 1960s Harvard expedition to the South Pacific, and 2) approximately 350 individuals of Gullah descent from South Carolina.  Web-based infrastructure (Figure 5) was created for storing the dental scans and genealogies (Figure 4) and a custom three dimensional scan viewer (Figure 3) was built for the website to allow direct data observation online. The link for this website is www.dentalphenomics.org.

There are numerous intellectual merits of this project. The PIs represent a cross-disciplinary cohort of scholars that combine expertise in dental anatomy with computer science. The research that results from the data collected will advance our understanding of what variation in teeth actually means with respect to underlying genetic variation at multiple scales, from individual level comparisons to comparisons across populations.  The biggest impact will be in the field of bioarchaeology (the analysis of skeletons from archaeological sites) where standards of data collection will be impacted by improving the way we collect data with respect to advances in our understanding of how teeth form and how variation is patterned within the dental arcade. Ultimately, this project should define new approaches for measuring and scoring teeth that improves our reconstructions of evolutionary processes (such as migration) in the past. The dissemination of the raw three dimensional scan files will allow researchers to define new types of traits that could prove more useful than traditional measurements for such interpretations. As such, there is transformative potential to this project. The knowledge developed from this project may also improve the clinical fields of dentistry and o...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Many people donÆt think about their teeth unless there is a problem. Yet teeth are one of the most useful and informative parts of the body. The outer enamel is the hardest substance in the human body and the dentition of an individual preserves important information about growth, the health of the individual, and what they ate. This is why archaeologists are so interested in the study of teeth from ancient societies – analyses of dentition provide unique windows into the lives of our ancestors, both relatively recent and ancient. Indeed, much of what we know about the deep past of life on this planet comes from teeth that have fossilized. Teeth are used to reconstruct evolutionary relationships between different species, to infer body size, and to reconstruct habitat and dietary focus. For humans, teeth are an important source of information on genealogical relationships, how cemeteries were organized, migration patterns, and patterns of relatedness between ancestor and descendant communities. The utility of teeth is more so evident in situations in which DNA does not preserve. But the relationship between tooth anatomy and genetics is poorly understood. This projectÆs ultimate goal is to improve our understanding of the relationships between genes and tooth appearance to better inform the analysis of evolutionary relationships in the past using the human skeleton as a proxy. To accomplish this, we proposed a scope of work that focused on collections of human dental casts (Figure 1) that were accompanied by genealogical information detailing how the individuals were related to each other (Figure 2). We collected data on tooth size, approximately three dozen standard observations on tooth anatomy (such as the number of cusps on a molar), scaled two dimensional images of the premolars and molars (to allow assessment of the arrangement of features on the chewing surface of the tooth– Figure 3), and three dimensional scans of complete dental casts (Figure 4). These data were recorded from dental casts for two different populations: 1) approximately 450 individuals from the Solomon Islands collected during the 1960s Harvard expedition to the South Pacific, and 2) approximately 350 individuals of Gullah descent from South Carolina. Web-based infrastructure (Figure 5) was created for storing the dental scans and genealogies (Figure 4) and a custom three dimensional scan viewer (Figure 3) was built for the website to allow direct data observation online. The link for this website is www.dentalphenomics.org. There are numerous intellectual merits of this project. The PIs represent a cross-disciplinary cohort of scholars that combine expertise in dental anatomy with computer science. The research that results from the data collected will advance our understanding of what variation in teeth actually means with respect to underlying genetic variation at multiple scales, from individual level comparisons to comparisons across populations. The biggest impact will be in the field of bioarchaeology (the analysis of skeletons from archaeological sites) where standards of data collection will be impacted by improving the way we collect data with respect to advances in our understanding of how teeth form and how variation is patterned within the dental arcade. Ultimately, this project should define new approaches for measuring and scoring teeth that improves our reconstructions of evolutionary processes (such as migration) in the past. The dissemination of the raw three dimensional scan files will allow researchers to define new types of traits that could prove more useful than traditional measurements for such interpretations. As such, there is transformative potential to this project. The knowledge developed from this project may also improve the clinical fields of dentistry and orthodontics as well as impact forensic odontology (victim identification, bite mark analysis), which has implications for law enforcement professio...
